text.p: The following are the main stories from Thursday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- 3,000 German soldiers to go to Balkans in multinational follow-on force
- Tchibo and Eduscho merge in coffee-market link-up
- Government cuts labour institute budget
- Full sick pay agreed in North Rhine-Westphalia engineering industry
HANDELSBLATT
- Hoechst restructures pharmaceuticals business
- Coffee-roaster Tchibo and Eduscho to merge
- VW ex-manager Lopez charged in Darmstadt
- Cabinet approves bill regulating multimedia
- Full sick pay agreed in North Rhine-Westphalia engineering industry
- Cabinet passes new law making it easier for companies to take up new capital
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- North Rhine-Westphalia engineering employers and workers reach pay deal
- CDU politicians expect higher value added tax
- VW ex-manager Lopez charged
- Cabinet approves new deployment of German troops in Bosnia
- Lufthansa faces strike
- German citizens' opposition to single currency grows
DIE WELT
- VW ex-manager Lopez charged
- Santer says EU must do more to fight unemployment
- Coalition parties may decide next week on cut in solidarity surcharge
- Parliament to debate new deployment of German troops in Bosnia
- Tchibo swallows Eduscho
- Bremer Vulkan situation increasingly perilous
- German citizens' fear of single currency grows
-- Bonn Newsroom +49 228 26097160
